titleStmt.title: The post of the prince which advises vs the taking of Steen Bergh. And the besieging of Berghen vp Zoom, with all the circumstances of the parleyes, assaults, sallies, and all what is done vntill this time, as well by the Spanish campe, as the states garrisons. And relates all the late newes of Europe. And principally all the late proceedings of the Prince Palatine, the Count Mansfield, the Duke of Brunsvvick, and the Marquis of Baden; besides, all the late warre like actions in Switzerland; the Grysons; and Low Countries.

titleStmt.title: The post of the prince which advises vs the taking of Steen Bergh. And the besieging of Berghen vp Zoom, with all the circumstances of the parleyes, assaults, sallies, and all what is done vntill this time, as well by the Spanish campe, as the states garrisons. And relates all the late newes of Europe. And principally all the late proceedings of the Prince Palatine, the Count Mansfield, the Duke of Brunsvvick, and the Marquis of Baden; besides, all the late warre like actions in Switzerland; the Grysons; and Low Countries.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: The 13. of Augu≈øt 1622.
THE POST OF THE PRINCE, WHICH ADVISES VS THE TAKING OF STEEN BERGH.

AND The Be≈øieging of Berghen vp Zoom, with all the Circum≈øtances of the Parleyes, A≈ø≈øaults, Sallies, and all what is done vntill this time, as well by the Spani≈øh Campe, as the States Garri≈øons.
And Relates all the late Newes of Europe.

And principally all the late Proceedings of the Prince PALATINE, the Count MANSFELD, the Duke of BRVNSVVICK, and the Marquis of BADEN; Be≈øides, all the late Warre like actions in Switzerland; the G ‚Ä¢ y≈øons; and Low Countries.
LONDON, Printed by I. D. for Nicholas Bourne and Thomas Archer, and are to be ≈øold at their ≈øhops at the Exchange, and in Popes-head Pallace. 1622.

div.head: THE POST OF THE PRINCE, which advi≈øes vs, the taking of Steen-Bergh, and the be≈øieging of Berghen vp Zoom.
div.p: SOme few dayes agoe the Marquis Spinola ≈øent certaine Companies towards Mastricht to cro≈ø≈øe there the River of the Maye, as if they ≈øhoulde haue marcht towards the Rhine, keeping neverthele≈ø≈øe the greate≈øt parts of his forces in Brabant, as if they were to follow the other but that was not his intent.
Satterday, Sunday, and Munday, there was given order to goe towards Mae≈øeyck, onely to deceiue the forces of the States.

The re≈øt pa≈øt by Brey, and Peer, whereupon followed the Garri≈øons of Bilzen, Ha≈ø≈øelt, Herck, Hall, Diest, Sichenen, Ar≈øchot, Loven,
Beringen, and Geell to the Hooghe-Straets, where tho≈øe of Liere, Mechesten, and Antwerpe met likewi≈øe, which all ioyned, made a great Armie, and was provided with Artillery, Gun-powder, Leade, and certaine Boates vpon Waggons with all nece≈ø≈øarie provi≈øions, for an enterpri≈øe In the meane time the Marquis with ≈øome few hor≈øe po≈øted to We≈øell, as if hee would haue ioyned with Count Henry of the Bergh, but hee returned pre≈øently.

The Prince of Orenge vnder≈øtanding this gaue command that the States hor≈øe in Brabant, ≈øhould ride to Bommelerwaert, and Nimwegen, little thinking what was the ≈øcope of the enemies. Wherupon certaine troops of hor≈øe of the Garri≈øon of Berghen vp zoom, being arrived at Breda, Iu≈øtinus of Na≈ø≈øaw Governour of Breda, having had ≈øome intelligence of the de≈ø≈øeing of Spinola, per≈øwaded them to returne backe, and told them that he was ≈øure that Spinola had an enterpri≈øe vpon Berghen vp Zoom.

The Leaders after a little deliberation, conde≈øcended all pre≈øently to his advi≈øe, notwith≈øtanding the command of the Prince
of Orange. As ≈øoone as they were return'd in their Garri≈øon, they vnder≈øtood, that the Spani≈øh Forces, twelue thou≈øand ≈øtrong, marched towards the Ca≈øtle of Wowe: And vpon the 18. of Iuly, the≈øe of Steen berghen perceived that their Towne was to be be≈øieged, being vnawares, and vnprovided of many things nece≈ø≈øary to ≈øu≈øtaine a ≈øiege, ≈øeeing it is a place of no great importance. Mon≈øieur Borwater Governour of the place, being a braue Souldier, was much di≈øcontented with this Newes, ≈øeeing he wanted both men and Munition, having but one peece of Ordinance in the Towne, and that vn≈øerviceable, layd before the Ho≈øpitall without the appurtenances. It is certaine, that the Prince of Orange few dayes before the ≈øiege, ≈øent thether a Gunner, and had given charge to a Commi≈ø≈øioner to convay thether fiue or ≈øix Cannons, but what≈øoever the cau≈øe is, it was not performed: And the Women of the Towne much di≈øcontented with the ≈øayd Commi≈ø≈øioner, would haue ca≈øt him the afore≈øayd Munday (being the 18. of Iuly) into the water; the ≈øaid day about
noone is the enemy come ≈øo neere to the Towne, that their voyces might be heard by the Garri≈øon, and turn'd pre≈øently their Ordinance, and di≈øcharged the ≈øame again≈øt the Towne, not having made any Battery.

And having made a rea≈øonable bigge breach in the walles with ≈øixtie Cannon ≈øhot, the Inhabitants began to looke heavie, the rather becau≈øe they had not heard of late the noy≈øe of ≈øuch Heath Crickets. A few houres before, went a great number of women and children, crying and lamenting, out of the Towne; which was certainely a pittifull ≈øpectacle to beholde.

What concernes the cryes and laments heard by me, as well of tho≈øe that were within as without Tertolen, the C'limder and the Plaet. I will not ≈øpeake of, they carry away all what they will not loo≈øe.

I could more liuely Relate how they cry and lament, and wring their hands together, the one, for her husband, the other, for her childe, leaping in and out the boats (≈øaying) that they will remayne, where fle≈øh and bloud is lo≈øt, goods are not remembered
in ≈øuch ca≈øes. In tho≈øe places where the≈øe things happen, there is no di≈øputing whether they be Papi≈øts, Prote≈øtants, or Arminians, but mu≈øt ioyntly re≈øi≈øt the inva≈øion of the enemies.

On thur≈øday the 19. of Iuly did the enemies ≈øend a Trumpet to the Towne, to aske whether they would Parley. That otherwi≈øe, his Forces ≈øtanding readie in Battell array, ≈øhould a≈ø≈øault the towne where the breach was made. Declaring moreover, that they would not depart from thence before they had brought the Towne vnder the obedience of the King of Spaine.

The valiant Governour Borwater, with two Captaines, and the Gentlemen of their Companies, and ≈øome of the Magi≈øtrats of the place, re≈øolved to keepe the Towne, vntill the la≈øt man, for the States. But they reque≈øted the Trumpet, that he would try whether the enemies would conde≈øcend to a ce≈ø≈øation of Armes for few houres onely; wherevpon, he returned pre≈øently to Don Lewis de V ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ yco, and the Governour of Antwerpe.

In the meane time, they ≈øent ≈øome to looke whether they could not ≈øee (≈øtanding vpon the Steeple) any Shippes comming with ayde.
But afterwards, ≈øeeing that the enemy divided his Forces in three ≈øeverall Troopes, to a≈ø≈øault the towne in divers places, and that they were not able to defend the ≈øame, ≈øeeing it had no Countre≈øcarps, or Bulwarkes, but onely certaine round Towers of no ≈øtrength. And likewi≈øe in con≈øideration of the lamentations of women and Cittizens which had any thing to loo≈øe, they could not re≈øolue almo≈øt what to doe. And to ≈øpeake the truth, there was no other i≈ø≈øue to be expected, then that the Souldiers, and armed Cittizens, ≈øhould be ≈ølaine, as al≈øo all the re≈øt, and all their goods pillaged, and made havock off.

At the ≈øame in≈øtant, the Trumpet being returned, told them that the enemy would not grant them as much as the ≈øpace of an houre. But if they would ≈øurrender the Towne, they ≈øhould haue good conditions, and be well v≈øed, otherwi≈øe they mu≈øt doe as the cau≈øe ≈øhould require.
The Governour was vnwilling to yeeld, but mo≈øt Voyces carryed away, and agreed vpon the≈øe following Conditions and Articles.
1. That all the Souldiers with their Armes and Armour, be≈øides Baggage ≈øhould depart, and be conducted with a ≈øafe Convoy.
2. That the Towne≈ømen ≈øhould pay two thou≈øand Gilders (which is 200.li. Sterling) to the Souldiers, to hinder their pillaging.
3. That all the Towne≈ømen after the afore≈øaid money is payd, ≈øhall haue libertie to depart with their goods where they li≈øt.

4. That tho≈øe that would remaine there, and liue according to their Lawes, Cu≈øtomes, and Ceremonies, they might, and ≈øhould be v≈øed as other Inhabitants of the obey≈øant Citties and Townes of Brabant.

Vpon the≈øe conditions is the Towne ≈øurrendered the afore≈øaid Munday before noone being the 19. of Iuly. The Governour had likewi≈øe leaue to convay his goods away. Within the Towne were two Companies, an old and a new, both of Alekmar, & behaved them≈øelues very valiantly.
At their departure there was a woman that philipping vpon her thumbe, told to ≈øome of the Souldiers, now you mu≈øt foorth and our friends ≈øhall come in.

This Towne was be≈øet with 9. Companies, and one Captaine Det (who did lie in former time vpon the Ca≈øtle of Wowe, and is very skilfull in pillaging, wherefore the Countrey peoof the Climder, Stryen, and the Plaet may looke to
them≈øelues, ≈øeing at the Land ≈øide he hath but a barren Heath) made Governour of the ≈øame.
At the Haven not farre from the Towne, is the Enemie ray≈øing a Fort compelling both Cittizens and Souldiers to labour at it.

They haue likewi≈øe put their boats to the water, which they haue gotten thither by wag gons, intending to trouble the Navigation betwixt Holland and Sealand. But our Mariners and Saylers wilbe very glad to meete with them.

As ≈øoone as the enemy had his garri≈øon planted in the Towne, he ≈øent his forces towards Berghen vp Zoom, but 2. Leagues from thence, the hor≈øe were conducted by Don Lewis de Vela≈øco, and the foote by the Governour of Antwerpe, marching ≈øo in all ha≈øt to the ≈øayd Citty, and being arrived there, planted their Ordinance not farre off, thinking to ≈øpeede as they did at Steene-berghen, having notice that the Hor≈øe in garri≈øon were abroad.

And towards the Evening they thought to ≈øurpri≈øe the horne-workes, or the great outworkes neere Saint Quirin; But the Governour Rhyhoven did hid him≈øelfe in the ≈øayd outworks commanding the Ordinance and all things nece≈ø≈øary to bee made readie again≈øt their approach. which being perceived, the Ordinance
was pre≈øently di≈øplayd again≈øt them, and our foote went to meete them, crying, kill, kill, kil, and after the ≈øound of the Trumpet, our hor≈øe likewi≈øe ≈øet vpon the Enemies, pur≈øuing them in ≈øuch maner vnto their Cannon, that a great ≈ølaughter was made among≈øt them, and if the garri≈øon had beene well ≈øeconded and refre≈øhed, they would haue carried it away, or otherwi≈øe nayled the ≈øame to make it vn≈øervi≈øeable: at our retreat the hor≈øe of the enemy prepared them≈øelues to ≈øet vpon our garri≈øon, but our Ordinance planted vpon the wals, cau≈øed both men and hor≈øes to cut capers in the ayre wherby there ro≈øe ≈øuch an Alarum with crying and lamenting among≈øt them, that it ≈øeemed that every one was hurt that came neere, them. In ≈øuch maner they haue beene twi≈øe or thri≈øe re≈øconcerned, and if they like it well they may come againe

But they di≈øliking much this dan≈øe, retyred pre≈øently a quarter of a myle, they tooke their men which were ≈ølaine along with them and rancked them in the ≈øand, ≈øaying the≈øe feare no more the Flamencos. In the meane time tho≈øe of the city ≈øpare no charges to fortifie them≈øelues, having pierced likewi≈øe the Beare of the newe worke neare the Haven.

The Prince of Orange as ≈øoone as he was informed of the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages, ≈øent thither on Thur≈øday the valiaÃÑt Collonel the Lord of Fama with a 100. ≈ømal ≈øhips loaden with armed ≈øouldIers, The next day, the Count Iohn of Na≈ø≈øaw, ≈øayled likewi≈øe with 100. ≈ømall Ships to the ≈øayd City, be≈øides the≈øe, there are many ≈øhips and men arrived from Zealand, in ≈øuch maner that the water ≈øeemed to be covered with Shippes and Boats.

Out of his Campe he di≈øpatcht likewi≈øe certaine troops of hor≈øe (which tooke their way by Hue≈øden, Gertruyen, Bergh, Oo ‚Ä¢ terhrut, and Breda) to endamage the Enemy before Berghen afore≈øayd. To day we are advi≈øed that there be aboue 5000. ≈øouldiers in Berghen vp Zoom, & that the Enemy hath lo≈øt 400.
The 19. of Iuly, there was brought in a Pri≈øe at Rotterdam, with 800. Che≈øts of Sugar.

div.head: The taking in of the Towne of Goch, in the land of Cleue, by the Marquis SPINOLA.
div.p:
ANno 1622. the 26.27. and 28. of Iuly, is the Marquis Spinola accompanied with Count Henry of the Bergh, and ≈øome Forces, marcht from Wezell towards the Ea≈øt ≈øide of the Rhine downward,
as if he would haue attempted ≈øomething again≈øt Doe≈øburgh, Zutphen, or Deventer.

The Prince of Orange well knowing his Stratagems, lookt about as well as he could. But Spinola having cho≈øen a fit time for him≈øelfe, ≈øtayed all Pa≈ø≈øengers at that in≈øtant, and drew in≈øtantly out of the next Citties and Townes of Cleue, a good part of the Garri≈øons with him, and ≈øet with the ≈øame vpon Goch. And having with his Ordinance beaten the Tyles from the hou≈øes, ≈øo that they fell in the Street, which cau≈øing the Towne≈ømen to run more to their Cellers then Walls, he got the Towne by compo≈øition the 28. of Iuly, ≈øeeing the Garri≈øon was but 300 men ≈øtrong, and not able to re≈øi≈øt with their willing hearts, his violences and Forces.

From Rome, La≈øt Sunday the Po≈øt (that was ≈øent by the Arch-Duke Leopoldus vnto the Pope reque≈øting his Holine≈ø≈øe that whereas he had certaine Souldiers in pay in Germany, vnder the Commaund of Don Pedro Alderbrandino, it would plea≈øe him to turne them over into his ≈øervice) hath beene di≈øpacht with this an≈øwere, that the Arch-Duke mu≈øt ≈øue for the ≈øame purpo≈øe vnto the Emperour.

La≈øt Wedne≈øday, the Amba≈ø≈øadour of the King of Spaine, did pre≈øent a hor≈øe, and a Letter
of Exchange of 7000. Crownes for the feude or fealtie of the Kingdome of Naples, which were accepted by the Procurator of the Exchequer; with the accu≈øtomed & v≈øual prote≈øtatioÃÑ.

We heare from Naples, that the Galleons with Souldiers lately ≈øayled towards Spaine are to be imployed again≈øt the Pirates: And that out of the ≈øayd Kingdomes 400000. Crownes, and from Sicilia 150000. Crownes ≈øhould be made over by Letters of Exchange in the Low Countries, towards the charges of the warre.

From Mes≈øina, they write that the Gallies of To≈øca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
were arrived at Reggio, having fought with 15. Ve≈ø≈øels of the Pyrats, and had made 250. of them ≈ølaues, and gotten 8. peeces of Ordinance from them, and one Ship loaden with Oyle, be≈øides 100000. Crownes for acompo≈øition or ran≈øome to ≈øaue their liues.

From Venice, Iuly 8. from Turine they advi≈øe that the Duke of Savoy, ray≈øeth many forces in France, and other countries, having ≈øent divers Inginers to fortifie his Fortre≈ø≈øes of Asti, Vercelli, and Saint Germane and other places. Morcover he hath ≈øupplied the garri≈øons of Asti, and Vercelli, with 400. Souldiers. And that Aldeibgera hath an army in readines vpon the confines of Savoy, for his Highnes ≈øervice.

Letters from Milane relate, that 100. cartes from thence were ≈øent with munition to the Veltolinas to prouide the ≈øouldiers withall, ≈øeeing that great forces are to be ≈øent thether again≈øt the Gri≈øons. The≈øouldiers which came with the Knight Plecch ‚Ä¢
from Al≈øatia are ≈øent towards Bormio. The Spaniards which haue layne in Cleue are marcht vp towards Millane, hauing left there onely the Counte Serbellione with his regiment. And heere are leauied with all ≈øpeed 11. trouppes of hor≈øe.

La≈øt Thu≈øday is the Knight Simon Contarini cho≈øen by this Signorie Amba≈ø≈øador for Con≈øtantinopele to congratulate the great Signor, who hath giuen two millons of gold to his Iani≈ø≈øaries, and increa≈øed their pen≈øion 3. a≈øpers a day.

From Brinoten the 10. daie the Confederates haue be≈øieged Guttenborg and di≈øcharge their ordinance again≈øt the ≈øame, doeing tho≈øe of the Towne the like: be≈øides they haue made a ≈øcon≈øe neere Vle≈øchenberg directly again≈øt the Towne to endammage the ≈øame, as likewi≈øe inuaded Manta≈øan, and a≈ø≈øaulted
the enemies in two a≈ø≈øunder places, which cau≈øeth great feare & dearth in Tirol.

The Confederates at Baden haue vnder hand & ≈øeale reniewed their confederation with the Graubuntens, whereupon they care now litle for Leopoldus and other enemies. Likewi≈øe the 5. Catholike Cantons haue promi≈øed free pa≈ø≈øage to the Reformed, vpon condition that they ≈øhal bring certificates or pa≈ø≈øeports from their Magi≈øtrates or Commanders. And they them≈øelfes haue adui≈øed the Prote≈øtantes to make no agreement with their enemies, but to go on with their enterpri≈øes, & to clen≈øe the countrie quit of them. When they haue taken Engadin, they intended to be≈øiege Veltkercken; they get daily great a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of men, munition, & ordinance, from the Bunoters.

From Prague the 12. of Iuly. The 7. of this moneth is the Count of Hoghen≈øoller (being Amba≈ø≈øer. of the Emp.) trauelled towards Dre≈øden vnto the Duke & Elector of Saxony) and to other places of the Empire.

Ye≈øterday the Commi≈ø≈øioners went al this Citie ouer, to vi≈øit the armes of the Prote≈øtants,
and left them only their rapers & daggers, after they had inrolled them in their bookes, to what purpo≈øe, we hnow not yet.

From Frankendall the 12. day Counte Man≈øfield & Duke Chri≈øtian of Brun≈øwick are marcht towards Luthenborch with an armie of 1100. hor≈øe and 25000. foote: and taking euerie where great contributions, and wee heare that they haue gotten 300000. Ryxdallers in Al≈øatia onely: and we looke what both the Imperiall armies will attempt. It is thought that they will pa≈ø≈øe ouer at Shrock and march from thence to New≈øtadt and Germer≈øheim.

All the forces by the Prince Palatine left in the Palatinate lie in garri≈øon, the hor≈øe onely excepted of Obertrout and Meganck which keepe about the Mountain. There is a ≈øtrong garri≈øon in this Towne, being two trouppes of hor≈øe among≈øt them, we are likewi≈øe very well prouided with all kinde of ordinance.

The Fort commenced by the Schaperie of this Town is made alreadie defen≈øible, and the workemen continue daily to worke at it. They ≈øay here that our Prince is gone towards Sedan, where the Duke of Boullion keepes his Court.
From Francfort the 21. Iulij, It is certaine that the Imperiali≈øts are retired from Heydelbergh. The Engli≈øh Amba≈ø≈øador laboureth hard to obtaine a truce, or a ce≈ø≈øatioÃÑ of armes.

Here is rumored that the Spani≈øh forces wil laie an other bridge at Stein to pa≈ø≈øe ouer the Rhine. The meane time are the Spani≈øh & Bauarian forces at Worms tran≈øported ouer the Rhyne with boates, but their baggage ≈øhalbe carried ouer the bridge at Vppenheim; and is like they will be≈øidge Franckendall.
The Counte of Anboult marching with his forces toward Al≈øatia did ≈øeiourn 3. daies agoe at Kerken two leagues but di≈øtant from Tourlach, what his intentioÃÑ is we know not:

The Landtgraue Lodewick of Darm≈øtad is retired vpon his fort Ru≈ø≈øe≈øheim, where he intends to abide for a time. Otherwi≈øe wee heare but litle of the ≈øouldiers, but that they ≈øometime with halfe Companies goe pilladging, and in ≈øuch manner was lately ran≈øackt and pillaged the Ca≈øtle of Offenback belonging to the Counte of I≈øenburgh.

The Spani≈øh armie lies at this pre≈øent at Lempertheym, and there comes newes that the
Bauarians haue fired Khonow, be≈øides 9. villages.

From Collen the 23 day, we hould for certaine that the fort of Papenmuts or Prie≈øts cap ≈øhalbe be≈øieged this night, ≈øeeing that ye≈øterday many ≈øouldiers vpwards coÃÑming from Du≈ø≈øeldorp and at Lul≈ødorp were certaine hundred arriued alreadie, & be≈øides other preparations; there is ≈øent a ≈ømall man of warre to coÃÑtinue at Lul≈ødorp. And we haue vnder≈øtood afterwards by the Country people, that the Batteries are made ready and the ordinance planted again≈øt the Fort.

From Emmerick, His Excellentie hath commanded a bridge to be ca≈øted ouer the riuer Wilde, & the ordinance and munition to be landed, whereof ≈øome was conueyed away by waggons ≈øo that by all likelyhoode it ≈øeemeth that he will attempt ≈øomething either again≈øt Groll or Olden≈øeel.
From Algiers we vnder≈øtaÃÑd that the plague there as likewi≈øe at Thunis, in ≈øuch a manner continued that there died about 500. a day.
The Corne is grown now better cheape in Italy.
The O≈øtendeners are almo≈øt all be≈øet in diuers parts by the men of warre of the States.

Counte Henry of the Berghe is marcht vp towards the riuer of the Ma≈øe with ≈øome 5. or 6000. men: hauing yet left many at We≈øel and Berck. The Prince of Orange was yet at Emerie where hee hauing gotten great ≈øtore of waggons, gaue charge the ordinance and munition to be carried awaie according to his direction, whereby it is ea≈øelie to be ge≈ø≈øed that he hath ≈øome enterpri≈øe in hand.

Tho≈øe of Lotharingia ≈øtand in great feare of Mansfield, ≈øeeing he will take his pa≈ø≈øage through the Countrie, and haue written vnto Spignola for aide, and that without the ≈øame they ≈øhalbe compelled to ≈øuffer him in their Territorie.

From Lip≈øich they write, that the the 6. of Iuly the Ladie of the Elector of Saxony is brought to bedde of a young Sonne, that there are now 5. Dukes aliue of his line. The Godfathers are the Duke of Mechelburg, the Duke Lunenburg of Zel, two Dukes of Gomeren, and the Ladys mother is the young Dukes Godmother.

The enemies fortifie daily their campe before Berghen op Zoom, & hauing made their Quarters and intrenched them≈øelues, they goe now to make batteries, and ≈øeeke to approach neerer the Cittie by trenches, but the garri≈øon playes brauelie with the ordinance vpon them, which being mo≈øt made of ≈øand, are many times ≈øpoyled and ≈øhot downe by the ordinance of the Cittie and manie of his ≈øouldiers ≈øhot to death; ≈øo that they beginne to perceiue that this will be an other O≈øtende and that they ≈øhalbe put to it very hardlie and dangerou≈øly, be≈øides all proui≈øion and prouande is among≈øt them a great deale deerer then it is in the Citty, ≈øeeing they mu≈øt get it by land, which cau≈øeth diuers to runne away. Within the Cittie and the outwarkes is great ≈øtore of good ≈øouldiers and braue Commanders, as likewi≈øe Ingeners, Miners, and Pioniers; be≈øides all other things nece≈ø≈øarie for their maintenance and defence. And all the forts in the Land of Tertolen be likewi≈øe well prouided.

Wee vnder≈øtand that the enemie hath ≈øent ≈øome more Artillerie, ammonution, &
other proui≈ø≈øion accompanied with a ≈øtrong conuay, being forced to doe this continually if he will continue the ≈øiege; the≈øe of the city goe ≈øometimes abroad to trie their fortunes, & tooke this weeke certaine cartes with proui≈øion, be≈øides diuers hor≈øe and pri≈øoners.
It is reported for certaine that the Marquis Spignloa is arriued at Antwerpe, intending his iourney very ≈øpeedely towards his campe before Berghen vp Zoom.

Tho≈øe of Breda haue lately taken away al the brewe kettles that were in the Villages thereabout becau≈øe the enemies ≈øhould not v≈øe them, and it is reported that they mu≈øt pay in their campe 8. ≈øtuyuers for a kanne of beere.
Tho≈øe of Groll haue made an excur≈øion this weeke, vnto Deuenter, and tooke diuers cattell from thence with them.
